author: By Steve Smith
title: Noah Creshevsky, Composer of ‘Hyperreal’ Music, Dies at 75
description: He built his musical works from myriad sampled sounds, including noises from the street as well as voices and instruments. He was also a respected teacher.
content: Noah Creshevsky, a composer of sophisticated, variegated electroacoustic works that mingled scraps of vocal and instrumental music, speech, outside noise, television snippets and other bits of sound, died on Dec. 3 at his home in Manhattan. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: What Will D.J.T. Do?
description: That’s the question that could define the Republican Party for years to come, even as the president’s time in Washington winds down.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Republicans Who Embraced Nihilism
description: The Supreme Court thwarts the latest Trumpist attack on American democracy.
content: What is left to say about a political party that would throw out millions of votes?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our 50 Most Popular Recipes of 2020
description: Cook the recipes readers obsessed over.
content: Spend the weekend with our most popular recipes of the year: Alison Roman’s caramelized shallot pasta (above); Ravneet Gill’s perfect chocolate chip cookies, adapted by Charlotte Druckman; Yasmin Fahr’s sheet-pan baked feta with broccolini; and many more in the collection below. (And don’t miss our roundups of our most popular desserts and vegetarian recipes.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Beneath a Full Moon, a Healing Ritual
description: A recent textile work by Diedrick Brackens responds to a startling statistic about the ongoing AIDS epidemic.
content: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work into context. This week, we’re looking at a recent piece by Diedrick Brackens, who is known for his woven textiles, which are the subject of a solo exhibition at the Blanton Museum of Art in Austin, Texas, on view through May 16, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Amid Pandemic, Scientists Reassess Routine Medical Care
description: All this year, patients stayed away from doctors’ offices in droves, postponing tests and treatments. Maybe there’s a silver lining.
content: For years, health researchers bemoaned what they saw as excessive medical care in the United States. Too many tests and treatments, they said, are unnecessary or even harmful, and add to the huge cost of health care in this country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eowyn Ivey
title: Stormy Fairy Tales
description: The children in these three new novels brave blizzards, witches and monsters to convey a heartening message: “We will weather this together.”
content: OTTO TATTERCOAT AND THE FOREST OF LOST THINGSBy Matilda Woods
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Vaccine Is on Its Way to Canada. Who Will Get It First?
description: Determining how to parcel out the long-awaited vaccine is not a simple task for the provinces.
content: When a vaccine for polio was announced in 1953, the CBC reported that in Canada, “the reaction was the same as at the end of a terrible war.” The 13,109 Canadians the Covid-19 has killed, the hundreds of thousands it has made ill and the economic turmoil it has brought to the nation also seem like the toll of a battle. The vaccine approved this week by Canada also seemed like if not an armistice, a turning point. The first shipment of the vaccine created by the American company Pfizer and a German firm, BioNTech, is likely to be still in transit this weekend, and the first inoculations could come as early as Tuesday. The initial quantities will be small compared with the millions of doses expected to arrive in the new year, making the first doses more an appetizer than a rollout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Charley Pride, Country Music’s First Black Superstar, Dies at 86
description: He cemented his place in the country pantheon in the 1970s with hits including “Kiss an Angel Good Mornin’” and “Is Anybody Goin’ to San Antone.”
content: Charley Pride, a son of sharecroppers who rose to become country music’s first Black superstar on the strength of hits including “Kiss an Angel Good Mornin’” and “Is Anybody Goin’ to San Antone,” died on Saturday in hospice care in Dallas. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: China, in Nudge to U.S., Makes a New Promise to Tackle Global Warming
description: Speaking at an online summit on the fifth anniversary of the Paris climate agreement, Xi Jinping said that China would reduce its carbon intensity by over 65 percent by 2030.
content: China on Saturday promised incremental new steps to address climate change in the next decade, but signaled that it would not reveal all of its plans before seeing the next moves taken by its main global rival, the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Luke Broadwater
title: Rallying Behind Trump, Most House Republicans Joined Failed Lawsuit
description: More than 60 percent of the chamber’s Republicans — including party leaders — signed onto a brief, underscoring the party’s willingness to back the president no matter how extreme the test.
content: WASHINGTON — In the hours before the Supreme Court rejected it, another 20 House Republicans — including their top leader — joined a legal brief on Friday supporting an extraordinary lawsuit seeking to overturn President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory, underscoring the increasingly extreme lengths to which many in the party are willing to go to invalidate the election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: Should Companies Require Employees to Take the Vaccine?
description: It’s a debate that’s roiling boardrooms around the world.
content: Starting today, we’ll deliver a special edition of the DealBook newsletter every Saturday on a single topic or theme, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of a hot-button issue. (If you don’t already receive the newsletter, sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: Say You Want to Build a Monolith
description: Experts in design and special effects said the monoliths appearing around the world are not that difficult to replicate. (That doesn’t mean you should try.)
content: Stuck inside, looking at social media on your phone, bored with what’s on streaming, it could start to seem like a good idea. A monolith, you might reason, could add a glimmer of mystery to your local wilderness, might make people laugh, or at least distract them with a literal shiny object.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Democrats, and Even Some Republicans, Cheer as Justices Spurn Trump
description: While a top legal expert exhaled that “Our institutions held,” the Texas Republican Party chairman suggested secession.
content: The rejection came swiftly. The celebrations came just as fast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs, Pranshu Verma and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: 4 Stabbed and One Shot as Trump Supporters and Opponents Clash
description: Supporters of the president in several cities said they were still convinced that the election was stolen, no matter what the courts say. Some confrontations with counterprotesters turned violent.
content: WASHINGTON — Incensed by a Supreme Court ruling that further dashed President Trump’s hopes of invalidating his November electoral defeat, thousands of his supporters marched in Washington and several state capitals on Saturday to protest what they contended, against all evidence, was a stolen election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Ivory, Mitch Smith, Jasmine C. Lee, Jordan Allen, Alex Lemonides, Barbara Harvey, Alex Leeds Matthews, Cierra S. Queen, Natasha Rodriguez and John Yoon
title: How many vaccine doses will your state get?
description: The first shipments of Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccine will not be enough to inoculate even just the medical workers and nursing home residents at the top of the waiting list. But if federal regulators grant emergency authorization, millions of doses will soon be shipped across the country, a small but tangible step toward ending the pandemic.
content: The first shipments of Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccine will not be enough to inoculate even just the medical workers and nursing home residents at the top of the waiting list. But if federal regulators grant emergency authorization, millions of doses will soon be shipped across the country, a small but tangible step toward ending the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough, Reed Abelson and Jan Hoffman
title: First Coronavirus Vaccines Head to States, Starting Historic Effort
description: Distributing supplies is a daunting logistical challenge, involving sophisticated tracking equipment, military contingencies and tight security.
content: At Novant Health in Winston-Salem, N.C., the new ultracold freezers are ready — enough to eventually house more than 500,000 doses of the first coronavirus vaccine approved in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. to Halt Subsidies for Fossil Fuel Projects Abroad
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has been positioning himself as a leader in fighting global warming, an area where he can make common cause with President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain promised on Friday to end direct taxpayer support for fossil fuel projects overseas as soon as possible, in a move designed to help position his country as a global leader in the battle to curb climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Federal Judge in Wisconsin Deals Trump Another Court Defeat
description: A Trump appointee in Milwaukee, Judge Brett H. Ludwig, dismissed a suit contesting the election with a withering rebuke.
content: A federal judge in Milwaukee on Saturday tossed out President Trump’s latest effort to overturn the election results in Wisconsin, dismissing the case and ruling that it had failed “as a matter of law and fact.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Justice Department Carries Out 10th Execution This Year
description: Alfred Bourgeois was put to death by lethal injection for murdering his 2-year-old daughter.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Friday executed Alfred Bourgeois, a 56-year-old inmate sentenced to death for murdering his 2-year-old daughter in 2002.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Executes Dissident Accused of Stoking Protests
description: Ruhollah Zam had been convicted of encouraging an antigovernment uprising in 2017 through a Telegram channel he ran from exile in France.
content: Iran executed a dissident on Saturday after convicting him of encouraging a wave of antigovernment protests in 2017 through an opposition Telegram channel he ran from exile in France, Iranian news outlets reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Wu
title: Facebook Cannot Buy Its Way Out of Competition
description: It wasn’t legal when John D. Rockefeller did it, and it’s still not legal.
content: The Federal Trade Commission and more than 40 states filed an antitrust suit against Facebook on Wednesday, prompting the company and its defenders to argue that Silicon Valley’s very way of doing business is under attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Selinger
title: Don’t Want to Spring for a Hot Tub? Try a Stock Tank Pool
description: Taking the plunge in troughs originally used to feed farm animals.
content: If you happened to find yourself scouring the internet in search of an Intex inflatable pool last spring, only to come up empty-handed, you had company. According to Sabeena Hickman, the president and chief executive of the Pool & Hot Tub Alliance, pool sales skyrocketed as Americans faced a quarantined season at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Trump Spurned New York, but Here’s How He’s Still Tied to the City
description: The president switched his residency to Florida, but his footprint in New York remains large. Should he return, this is what he’d come home to.
content: He was the first New York City-born American president since Theodore Roosevelt, but as Donald J. Trump’s days at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue come to a close, his relationship with his hometown appears broken beyond repair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams
title: The Blue Flame of ‘Hotlanta’
description: Young entrepreneurs, artists and activists are building on a Southern capital’s long, rich history.
content: When Georgia went blue for Biden last month, some traced it to Stacey Abrams and her nonprofit Fair Fight, whose get-out-the-vote playbook electrified the state. Others cited more college-educated and older suburban voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Much Do I Tip the Building Staff During the Covid Holidays?
description: If ever there were a year to open your wallet wide, this is the one. But for New Yorkers who aren’t able to give this year, there are alternatives to cash.
content: Q: Holiday tipping is a mystery to me. I know I am supposed to tip the staff of my Upper West Side co-op, but I never know how much. This year, the question seems complicated by the pandemic. Tell me, how much should I give?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg and Nick Corasaniti
title: ‘An Indelible Stain’: How the G.O.P. Tried to Topple a Pillar of Democracy
description: The Supreme Court repudiation of President Trump was also a blunt rebuke to Republican leaders who had put their interests ahead of the country’s.
content: The Supreme Court repudiation of President Trump’s desperate bid for a second term not only shredded his effort to overturn the will of voters: It also was a blunt rebuke to Republican leaders in Congress and the states who were willing to damage American democracy by embracing a partisan power grab over a free and fair election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Pregnant and Breastfeeding Women May Opt to Receive the Vaccine
description: Although no coronavirus vaccine has been studied in these women, many scientists believe the benefits will outweigh any potential risks.
content: In its emergency authorization of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine on Friday night, the Food and Drug Administration took an unexpected step, leaving open the possibility that pregnant and breastfeeding women may opt for immunization against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Roblox Delays I.P.O. Until Next Year
description: After witnessing head-turning results for the initial public offerings by Airbnb and DoorDash, the gaming company said it would wait to test the market.
content: Roblox, a gaming company that had been preparing to go public this month, has decided to delay its initial public offering until next year, in a sign that the enthusiastic market for I.P.O.s by DoorDash and Airbnb this past week has made it difficult to price shares accurately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 51 Years Later, Coded Message Attributed to Zodiac Killer Has Been Solved, F.B.I. Says
description: The code had long baffled cryptographers, law enforcement agents and armchair sleuths obsessed with the shadowy killer, who was blamed for five murders in the late 1960s.
content: It took 51 years to crack, but one of the taunting messages written in code and attributed to the Zodiac Killer has been solved, according to the F.B.I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember and Katie Glueck
title: Biden’s Iowa Bus Tour Is Headed for a D.C. Reunion
description: A year ago, Joe Biden was on a grim bus tour through Iowa, joined by many old friends, including Tom Vilsack and John Kerry. Now Mr. Biden wants to bring some of the crew back to Washington with him.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. wasn’t the main event, and he knew it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Build on Common Ground
description: There is progress to be made on policies most Americans support.
content: Promises to pursue national healing and unity helped put Joe Biden in the White House. Americans embraced that vision. But the overall election results, with Republicans gaining seats in the House and possibly retaining control of the Senate, both exposed and increased the magnitude of the incoming president’s challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: Meet the Electoral College’s Biggest Critics: Some of the Electors Themselves
description: “Do we really want 538 Bob Nemanichs electing our president?” Bob Nemanich, a former elector, doesn’t. And he is hopeful that 2020 might put future electors out of a gig.
content: Few critics of the Electoral College are quite like Polly Baca.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Protests Erupt as South Korea’s Most Notorious Rapist Walks Free
description: Cho Doo-soon served 12 years in prison for raping an 8-year-old girl. His case has led the national legislature to create new rules for sex offenders released from prison.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea’s most infamous rapist was released on Saturday after serving 12 years in prison, sparking angry demonstrations and anonymous death threats that led to an increased police presence outside the predator’s home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: All Fish and No Chips
description: Brexit negotiations continue to limp along as a deadline looms.
content: It is hard to recall another negotiating process with as many ups and downs or as many make-or-break deadlines as Brexit. The next deadline, which in principle should conclude the divorce between Britain and the European Union, is Dec. 31. That is when a new trade agreement is supposed to be signed and sealed, clearing the way for Britain and the E.U. to finally start leading their separate lives. But for that to happen, a few knots have to be unraveled, and for that the deadline is Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: They Cover All of the Bases
description: Sid Sivakumar and Brooke Husic come around again, on a Saturday.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the second time this year that Sid Sivakumar and Brooke Husic have ganged up on us with a Saturday grid full of inventive combinations and debuts. This time I was hung up on a lot of misdirects, including a couple of big ones in the middle chunk, and I thought the southeast corner was really tough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines and Amy Harmon
title: What Happens When a Superspreader Event Keeps Spreading
description: A February conference by the drug company Biogen was initially thought to have infected 99 people. By the end of October, it was feared that the number had grown as high as 300,000.
content: WASHINGTON — When it was disclosed last spring that the coronavirus had stealthily infected 99 people after the Cambridge, Mass., pharmaceutical company Biogen held a two-day conference in February, it helped add the term “superspreader” to the pandemic lexicon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin and Kate Taylor
title: In Arizona, one of the hardest hit states in the nation, 100 teachers protested by calling in sick.
description: About 100 teachers in Arizona’s third-largest school district staged a sickout on Friday, demanding that schools close after winter break and stay remote until the region’s positivity rate declines.
content: About 100 teachers in Arizona’s third-largest school district staged a sickout on Friday, demanding that schools close after winter break and stay remote until the region’s positivity rate declines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: C.D.C. Panel Recommends Pfizer Vaccine for Patients as Young as 16
description: The advisory panel of experts endorsed the vaccine and will soon issue specific guidance for pregnant and lactating women and for people who have had severe allergic reactions to other shots.
content: An independent committee of experts advising the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Saturday afternoon voted to recommend the Pfizer coronavirus vaccine for people 16 and older. That endorsement, which now awaits only final approval by Dr. Robert Redfield, the director of the C.D.C., is a key signal to hospitals and doctors that they should proceed to inoculate patients.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: College Sports Has Reported At Least 6,629 Virus Cases. There Are Many More.
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 12, 2020.
content: “We felt there was nothing to hide.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Texas Lawsuit and the Age of Dreampolitik
description: The separation of political reality from political fantasy stills exists — for now.
content: When it comes to Donald Trump’s efforts to claim victory in the 2020 presidential election, there are two Republican Parties. One G.O.P. has behaved entirely normally, certifying elections, rejecting frivolous claims and conspiratorial lawsuits, declining to indulge the conceit that state legislatures might substitute their votes for the electoral outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: ‘Free Papua Movement’ Intensifies Amid Escalating Violence
description: West Papua was annexed by Indonesia decades ago, leading to a prolonged conflict. A tribal chief who lives overseas recently declared himself president of the embattled territory.
content: BANGKOK — It has been 59 years since separatists in the Indonesian territory of West Papua raised their red, white and blue flag and declared independence. The region has been in conflict ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Big Day for Mets Includes a New Catcher and a New G.M.
description: A four-year $40 million deal for James McCann should leave the Mets’ new general manager, Jared Porter, plenty of money to spend on other free agents.
content: Steven A. Cohen and his wife, Alex, spent part of their Saturday outside Citi Field, in the chill and the drizzle, greeting Mets season-ticket holders who stopped by for a bobblehead promotion. By the end of the day, the fans had more than trinkets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul and Nicholas Fandos
title: Republicans Find Themselves Speechless Following a Supreme Court Defeat
description: A ruling against President Trump appears to leave no avenue forward for the president, forcing Republicans to “play the hand we’re dealt.”
content: A day after President Trump’s stinging defeat in the Supreme Court, Republicans around the country seemed to be having trouble finding the right words.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Vaccines for Americans are just around the corner.
content: The Food and Drug Administration is expected to issue an emergency authorization for Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine on Friday evening — a historic turning point in a pandemic that has taken more than 294,000 lives in the United States alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Carlisle
title: Swimming Against Time, Ignoring the Finish Line
description: Swimming the 12 miles across Lake Tahoe, the author was advised to not look ahead but break up the challenge into fathomable chunks. It worked for the swim, and life.
content: For me, a 24-year-old software engineer whose pathetic swim career was best known for a Speedo malfunction while diving into a pool, the challenge was way, way over my head: Swim the 12 miles across a  chilly Lake Tahoe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: AstraZeneca to Buy Alexion for $39 Billion to Add Rare-Disease Treatments
description: The deal for the biopharmaceutical company is the latest big takeover this year, even amid the pandemic.
content: LONDON — The drug maker AstraZeneca agreed on Saturday to buy Alexion, a biopharmaceutical company, for $39 billion in cash and stock, as corporate giants resume big-ticket takeovers, even amid the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Bhutan Becomes Latest Asian Nation to Dial Back Anti-Gay Laws
description: Lawmakers in the Himalayan country voted this week to amend a 2004 law that criminalizes “sexual conduct that is against the order of nature,” previously treated as a reference to gay sex.
content: HONG KONG — The kingdom of Bhutan prides itself on maximizing “gross national happiness,” but it doesn’t always feel that way to members of the country’s L.G.B.T. community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
title: Treasure Washes Up on Venezuela’s Shore, Bringing Gold and Hope to a Village
description: Venezuela’s economic meltdown had pummeled a proud fishing village. Then jewelry started mysteriously surfacing on its beach, easing the pain of an economic crisis.
content: GUACA, Venezuela — The most extraordinary moment in the young fisherman’s life began in the most mundane way: with a morning visit to the latrine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Annie Karni
title: Biden Faces Intense Pressure From All Sides as He Seeks Diverse Cabinet
description: The pressure on the Democratic president-elect is intense, even as his efforts to ensure ethnic and gender diversity already go far beyond those of President Trump. And it’s coming from all sides.
content: WASHINGTON — The head of the N.A.A.C.P. had a blunt warning for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. when Mr. Biden met with civil rights leaders in Wilmington this week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nigerian Military in Firefight With Gang That Kidnapped Students
description: The country’s president said the kidnappers had been found in a forest, in northwest Katsina state, where a secondary school was attacked Friday, and which has been plagued by violence from outlaw gangs.
content: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria, (Reuters) — The Nigerian military engaged in a firefight Saturday with gunmen who had kidnapped scores of secondary school students in northwestern Katsina state the night before, the country’s president said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Los Angeles County could face ‘catastrophic suffering and death,’ a health official warns.
description: Los Angeles County could see “catastrophic suffering and death” in the coming weeks, public health officials warn, as the nation’s most populous county reported another record day of new coronavirus cases.
content: Los Angeles County could see “catastrophic suffering and death” in the coming weeks, public health officials warn, as the nation’s most populous county reported another record day of new coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: 10 Months Later, Iowa Democrats Blame National Party for Caucus Meltdown
description: With the future of Iowa’s first-in-the-nation Democratic caucuses in jeopardy, the state party sought to shift blame for a breakdown that delayed results for days after the Feb. 3 contest.
content: With Iowa’s closely watched presidential caucuses more endangered than ever after a disastrous showing in February that delayed results for days, the Iowa Democratic Party on Saturday sought to shift blame for the meltdown onto the Democratic National Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Al Gore
title: Al Gore: Where I Find Hope
description: The Biden administration will have the opportunity to restore confidence in America and take on the worsening climate crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Suderman
title: This Blockbuster Is Coming to a Living Room Near You
description: The next generation of event viewing is likely to look more like ‘Game of Thrones’ and less like ‘Tenet.’
content: In the 1970s, movies like “Jaws” and “Star Wars” proved that audiences would turn out in droves for event films. In the decades since, Hollywood has lived and died by the blockbuster, and so has American pop culture.Studios were defined by their blockbusters, giant investments in search of even bigger returns: “Star Wars” (again) and the Marvel Comics superhero films, “Harry Potter” and “The Fast and the Furious.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Ivory, Robert Gebeloff and Sarah Mervosh
title: Young People Have Less Covid-19 Risk, but in College Towns, Deaths Rose Fast
description: Links between university outbreaks and deaths in the wider community are often indirect and difficult to document, but some health experts say there are clear signs of a connection.
content: When college students returned to campuses around the country this fall, spurring a spike in new coronavirus infections nationwide, people like Phyllis Baukol seemed at little risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Lawrence Byrne, Former Lawyer for New York Police, Dies at 61
description: His younger brother, a police officer, was assassinated by a drug gang at 22, a key moment in the city’s crack epidemic of the 1980s.
content: Lawrence M. Byrne, who as the top lawyer for the New York City Police Department defended several hotly disputed police policies and who also kept alive the legacy of his brother, a rookie police officer who was executed by a drug gang, died on Dec. 6 in Manhattan. He was 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Jesse McKinley
title: Cuomo tries to jolt New Yorkers by warning of overwhelmed hospitals.
description: With coronavirus cases surging, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has shifted his strategy sharply away from tackling local clusters and toward protecting the state’s health system in a bid to avoid a return to the worst days of spring, when hospitals were stretched to the limit.
content: With coronavirus cases surging, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has shifted his strategy sharply away from tackling local clusters and toward protecting the state’s health system in a bid to avoid a return to the worst days of spring, when hospitals were stretched to the limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Spiral
description: Will Shortz hypnotizes us with a confounding coil of clues.
content: SPIRAL — Will Shortz is the Jedi master of this elegant variety puzzle, which is easy to explain — two strings of clues, running in opposite directions, share one set of letters — but tricky to settle into and solve. It always takes me several hesitations and false starts, especially when the first entries that I feel confident about are in the middle of the spiral, and not on one end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Cinéma Vérité
description: Dan Margolis reminds us of something we’re missing with his Sunday debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you take note of the title of the Sunday puzzle before you start it, this grid by Dan Margolis, his Sunday debut, makes a marvelous sort of sense. It’s disarmingly uncontrived; once I realized that, I found it a very relaxing, meditative kind of solve. It’s not easy, and there are a lot of fizzy elements throughout, but there’s a certain flow. Maybe it’s just me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: How the Vaccine Rollout Will Compare in Britain, Canada and the U.S.
description: Within days, all three countries could be giving the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, but they have varying strategies and challenges. The U.S. plan, working through the states, is the least centralized.
content: With the Food and Drug Administration’s authorization of a coronavirus vaccine on Friday, the United States became the third highly developed Western country — after Britain and Canada — to approve such a shot, and is expected to start inoculating people within days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas, Sharon LaFraniere, Noah Weiland, Abby Goodnough and Maggie Haberman
title: F.D.A. Clears Pfizer Vaccine, and Millions of Doses Will Be Shipped Right Away
description: An initial shipment of about 2.9 million doses of the vaccine will be sent around the United States over the next week.
content: The Food and Drug Administration authorized Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use on Friday, clearing the way for millions of highly vulnerable people to begin receiving the vaccine within days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Katie Thomas
title: UPS and FedEx say plans to ship the vaccine are underway.
description: UPS and FedEx, normally rivals, are working side by side to ship the coronavirus vaccine developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, the first of the vaccines to win U.S. government approval.
content: UPS and FedEx, normally rivals, are working side by side to ship the coronavirus vaccine developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, the first of the vaccines to win U.S. government approval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Jesse McKinley
title: Cuomo Tries to Jolt Public by Warning of Overwhelmed Hospitals
description: The governor makes a sharp strategic shift to persuade New Yorkers to take the coronavirus seriously as infections surge across the state.
content: With coronavirus cases surging, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has shifted his strategy sharply away from tackling local clusters and toward protecting the state’s health system in a bid to avoid a return to the worst days of spring, when hospitals were stretched to the limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Virus Cases in College Sports Prove Athletes Are Workers
description: They should be treated as such.
content: How much longer can the powers that run college sports turn a blind eye to player safety and the health of our communities?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo
title: Thousands of Photographs, and a Year Like No Other
description: The Year in Pictures project is an annual celebration of photojournalism. In 2020, photographers were living what they captured.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Jerrold M. Post, Specialist in Political Psychology, Dies at 83
description: He invented the field at the C.I.A., producing influential “psychobiographies” of world leaders. He later used the same methods to analyze Donald Trump.
content: In August 1978, shortly before the opening of negotiations between Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt at Camp David, President Jimmy Carter paid a visit to C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: Inside One Woman’s Quest to Preserve the Disappearing Southern Appalachia
description: Among the last in her community, an 89-year-old woman self-published a memoir about life in the mountains, where a number of Black families settled after the end of the Civil War.
content: Mary Othella Burnette was born and raised in western North Carolina, in a small community in the mountains where a number of Black families settled after the end of the Civil War. Enslaved people, newly freed from local plantations, put down roots there, and Ms. Burnette is related to many of the earliest settlers of what is known as Southern Appalachia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: ‘Very High Risk’: Longshoremen Want Protection From the Virus So They Can Stay on the Job
description: Port workers want early access to the coronavirus vaccine so they can prevent outbreaks that could shut down the nation’s ports and further damage the economy.
content: NEW ORLEANS — It was shortly after Mardi Gras, and Robert D. Givens thought he had a sinus infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: This Is the Test of Our Lifetimes
description: More Americans have died from Covid-19 than perished in four years of combat in World War II.
content: This should be a season of hope: We will shortly be getting a highly effective coronavirus vaccine, and the pandemic should wind down in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: An Epic Israeli TV Drama Exposes War Wounds Old and New
description: Grappling with the traumatic opening of the 1973 war, when Israel feared destruction, the series “Valley of Tears” has prompted a national outpouring of emotion.
content: JERUSALEM — A new Israeli television series based on true events from the 1973 war, when the country was caught off guard on the holiest day of the Jewish calendar and feared total destruction, has prompted an intense public reckoning with the scope of war trauma and the treatment of survivors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze, Richard C. Paddock and Dera Menra Sijabat
title: A German-Vietnamese social media star dies at 29, and other news from around the world.
description: Brittanya Karma posted her bucket list on Instagram last year.
content: Brittanya Karma posted her bucket list on Instagram last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Trump Castigates Barr for Not Publicly Disclosing Hunter Biden Investigation
description: The critical tweets echoed the president’s attacks on Jeff Sessions, his first attorney general.
content: President Trump on Saturday excoriated Attorney General William P. Barr, castigating him on Twitter for not violating Justice Department policy to publicly reveal an investigation into President-Elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: As France Shifts Right, a Hard-Line Minister Proves Indispensable to Macron
description: Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin has become a useful tool for the French president as he responds to growing calls for law and order following a spate of terror attacks.
content: PARIS — He has declared war on the Islamist “enemy within” and halal food shelves in supermarkets. He launched what he described as a “massive” operation against 76 of France’s mosques, and sought to criminalize the filming of police officers. And he announced that he “can’t breathe” when he hears the term “police violence” — mocking a cry against police brutality that originated in the United States and resonated around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Zissu
title: Saunas Are Hot
description: Enthusiasts swear there’s no better place to shut out (and sweat out) the world’s current cares.
content: In June, Lauren Warren bought a sauna after monitoring a sale on Wayfair.com and installed it in her living room. “With the winter coming — I really loathe winter — especially with the pandemic, I knew I wasn’t going to be able to get away to get warm,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisa Gabbert
title: The Best Poetry of 2020
description: Our poetry columnist picks some of her favorite collections of the year.
content: I’m uncomfortable using the word “best” on a list — in part because I am just one person whose tastes are subjective. More so, to me it implies that I’ve read every book that came out in 2020 and can therefore rank them like brands of peanut butter (which seem more finite). I didn’t read them all, or even close — I wish my life made that possible. Still, I couldn’t pass up the opportunity to talk about some poetry books that I loved this year. My column gives me limited space, so apart from the books I’ve already had a chance to recommend (like Don Mee Choi’s National Book Award-winning “DMZ Colony” or Chessy Normile’s great debut), here are several collections that I wasn’t able to write about in full or otherwise feel deserve more attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Marks and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: As War Goes On in Ethiopia, Ethnic Harassment Is on the Rise
description: Ethnic Tigray people all over the country report an increase in discrimination and abuse from the authorities.
content: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — On a bright day in mid-November, about a dozen police officers with machine guns barged into the home of Lisanewerk Desta, a theologian who is the head of the library and museum department at the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, and got to work.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trying to Understand What Drives People to Suicide
description: Readers, including those who have attempted suicide or who have lost family members, offer their insights.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 12, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 12, 2020.
content: An article on Tuesday about the latest lockdown in California misstated the capacity at which supermarkets can operate under new coronavirus restrictions. They can operate with 35 percent capacity, not 20 percent, after the state modified the original stay-at-home order.
source.name: The New York Times
